title: Penelope's Experiences in Scotland; Being Extracts from the Commonplace Book of Penelope Hamilton
author: Wiggin, Kate Douglas Smith
snippet: 'The Esk was swollen sae red an' sae deep,   But shouther to shouther the brave lads keep;   Twa thousand swam owre to fell English ground,   An' danced themselves dry to the pibroch's sound.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: The banks of the Esk were beautiful as ever; but, to Philip'seyes, they had lost great part of their attraction; he had had a glimpseof the scenes of active life, and he was eager to engage in them.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 14
author: Various
snippet: On the banks of the Esk, in the County of Dumfries, stood, some yearssince, a handsome, substantial-looking mansion, bearing all the marks ofplenty and comfort; while the neat and elegant arrangement of thegrounds around bore evidence to the refined and chaste taste of itsproprietor, Gavin Douglas.

title: Guy Mannering
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Thislong-shafted trident called a waster, [*Or leister. The long spearis used for striking; but there is a shorter, which is cast fromthe hand, and with which an experienced sportsman hits the fishwith singular dexterity.] is much practised at the mouth of theEsk, and in the other salmon rivers of Scotland.

title: Guy Mannering, Or, the Astrologer - Complete

snippet: Thischase, in which the fish is pursued and struck with barbed spears,or a sort of long-shafted trident, called a waster, is muchpractised at the mouth of the Esk and in the other salmon riversof Scotland.

title: Essays of travel and in the art of writing,
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: The character of the neighbourhood is pretty strongly marked by a scarcity of hedges ; by many stone walls of varying  heights ; by a fair amount of timber, some of it well grown, but apt to be of a bushy, northern profile and poor in foliage; by here and there a little river, Esk or Leith or Almond, busily journeying  in the bottom of its glen ; and from almost every point, by a peep of the sea or the hills.

title: Bonnie Scotland.

title: Provost-Marshal: a romance of the middle shires
author: Moncreiff, Frederick Charles
snippet: Yehave never heard tell in these parts of one PhilipThormington or Græme, alias Brother Philip, asthey say in their barbarous manner ?
